awd_titl_txt: CPS: Small: Collaborative Research: Information Design and Price Mechanisms in Platforms for Cyber-Physical Systems with Learning Agents
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is new theory for architectures for crowdsourced markets for cyber-physical systems (CPS), such as power systems and shared vehicle systems. A technology-enabled platform digitally mediates transactions between buyers (e.g., energy consumers/riders) and sellers (e.g., generators/drivers) helping to determine prices and pair buyers and sellers. Large-scale CPS impose fundamental physical constraints than traditional 'cyber' platforms, including environmental uncertainty, spatial difference, delay, and limited resources. The broader impacts of the work include mentoring with high-school students and teachers.

The project aims to develop guidance for optimal platform design. A central challenge is the complex behavior of agents, which possess limited information and receive limited feedback about how their actions translate to payoffs, and learn continuously over time to discover optimal strategies. The focus of the project is on the design of two significant levers available to the platform: information feedback and price-setting mechanisms. The research agenda is divided into two thrusts: (1) characterization of the dynamical behavior of agents under limited feedback; and (2) platform design through information sharing and pricing. In the first thrust, each agent is assumed to use a reasonable, `natural' learning algorithm and the goal is to understand how mechanisms available to the platform impact the learning process and eventual collective behavior. Outcomes from the first thrust will feed directly into the second, where the primary aim is to design information mechanisms to supplement pricing in order to shape the aggregate behavior of agents.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
This project developed new theory for architectures of crowdsourced markets within societal-scale cyber-physical systems (CPS), such as power systems and shared vehicle markets. In such systems, a technology-enabled platform digitally mediates transactions between buyers (e.g., energy consumers/riders) and sellers (e.g., generators/drivers) thereby helping to determine prices and match buyers and sellers. Large-scale CPS impose fundamental physical constraints beyond those in traditional 'cyber only' platforms, including environmental uncertainty, spatial difference, information asymmetries and delays, strategic behavior, and limited resources. These challenges demand robust, rigorous platform design in order to efficiently shape collective behavior. The rich theoretical agenda of the project was accompanied by education and outreach activities.

The project centered on developing guidance for optimal platform design. A key challenge to this aim is the complex, often strategic, behavior of agents which  possess limited information and receive limited feedback about how their actions translate to payoffs. Moreover, agents learn continuously over time in a coupled time-varying processes as they grapple to discover optimal strategies. The project tackled the design of two significant levers available to the platform: information feedback and price-setting mechanisms. Towards this end, the research agenda was divided into two thrusts: (1) characterization of the dynamical behavior of heterogeneous learning agents under limited feedback; and (2) platform design through information sharing and pricing schemes. In the first thrust, each agent was assumed to use a reasonable, `natural' learning algorithm and the project developed theory for modeling how mechanisms available to the platform impact the learning process and eventual collective behavior. Outcomes from the first thrust fed directly into the second, wherein the primary aim was to design algorithmic information distribution mechanisms to supplement pricing in order to shape the aggregate behavior of agents. Overall, the project produced theoretical analysis for long-run behavior of collections of heterogenous learning agents, and algorithms to strategically procure data that is then used to design and synthesize mechanisms to guide collective agent and platform behavior to more efficient, robust outcomes. 


Last Modified: 02/12/2024
Modified by: Lillian Ratliff
